pr_title: [RW-5028][RISK=NO] use partition time to scan many fewer partitions

timeline.message: use partition time to scan many fewer partitions

timeline.bodyText:
Will @after always be equal to a day boundary?  If not, this query will miss 23:59:59 worth of events in the worst case.  Choosing (@after - 1 day <= partition) is safer, and only scans 1 extraneous partition in the worst case.
Actually... are we guaranteed to have a partition daily?  Maybe increase that safety buffer.
The @before check looks fine.
timeline.author: jmthibault79
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -38,11 +38,13 @@
           + "  jsonPayload.prev_value AS prev_value,\n"
           + "  jsonPayload.new_value AS new_value\n"
           + "FROM %s\n"
-          + "WHERE %s AND\n"
-          + "  @after <= TIMESTAMP_MILLIS(CAST(jsonPayload.timestamp AS INT64)) AND\n"
-          + "  TIMESTAMP_MILLIS(CAST(jsonPayload.timestamp AS INT64)) < @before\n"
+          + "WHERE %s\n"
+          + "  AND @after <= TIMESTAMP_MILLIS(CAST(jsonPayload.timestamp AS INT64))\n"
+          + "  AND TIMESTAMP_MILLIS(CAST(jsonPayload.timestamp AS INT64)) < @before\n"
+          + "  AND @after <= _PARTITIONTIME\n"

replies.bodyText: You're right. I missed the boundary condition there.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Additionally, the event timestamps in the JSON payload predate (hopefully!) the BQ ingestion timestamps (which are the basis for partition determination) by delays in logging and sinking to BQ. Maybe a buffer of 1 day on either side is prudent.
replies.author: jaycarlton

timeline.message: fix partition times, remove joda-time, and make query replacement method work with substrings of parameter names
move utility methods to shared util class

timeline.bodyText: It just now occurred to me that I can use regex Patterns with word boundaries to solve this issue, and avoid re-sorting the whole list and lots of this code. All in favor of less code in this function?
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: not sure this is needed but it doesn't cost us much
timeline.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText: I like to use immutable types whenever possible as return values.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I mean that I don't think adding one day to "before" is necessary.
replies.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText: Oh, the timestamp I send to StackDriver is generally earlier than the ingestion time (which is what counts). So if I have an event at 23:59:30, it might have an ingestion timestamp of 00:00:30 on the next day. But you're right that that's fixable by moving before to the right.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: OK - safer to keep this then.  thanks!
replies.author: jmthibault79

timeline.bodyText: these look right but could you swap the order?
timeline.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText: I swapped it, but we're not asserting about the relative order of clauses in the query. That should be able to change without breaking the test.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Yes - I meant this only for reading
replies.author: jmthibault79

timeline.message: back out the header comment; was having issues in formatting and serialization

timeline.bodyText: Should this be .02Z like the others?
timeline.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText: No, the event time doesn't need to know what my after/before times are.
replies.author: jaycarlton
